titleStmt.title: Twitter Thread: African Tribes and Cultures featured in the Film Black Panther
Digital Edition

author.orgName: African American History, Culture, an Digital Humanities (AADHum)Initiative

respStmt.orgName: Maryland Institute for Technology in the Humanities (MITH)

extent.measure: 28 of the tweets in the thread were encoded.

publisher.orgName: African American History, Culture, and Digital Humanities (AADHum) Initiative

seriesStmt.title: Encoding for Black Lives: Legacies of Resistance and Reinvention in the (Re)Making of Black Freedom Online
Black Panther

bibl.title: Thread on African tribes/cultures featured in #BlackPanther. #Wakanda
bibl.author: @diasporicblues This is a twitter handle.
bibl.pubPlace: Twitter.com This is a Black place considering many twitter users are Black and use "Black Twitter" as a way to express their beliefs, feelings, and attitudes towards different aspects of the world around them.

bibl.title: Reckoning with Freedom
Legacies of Exclusion, Dehumanization, and Black Resistance in the Rhetoric of the Freedmen's Bureau

analytic.title: The Digital Barbershop: Blogs and Online Oral Culture Within the African American Community

imprint.publisher: University of Maryland Department of Communications

biblStruct.note: In this article, Catherine Knight Steele explores nine blogs by various African Americans in order to analyze the rhetorical strategies they use. She found that online spaces have become comparable to Black barbershops and beauty shops in that Black people have begun to use the same rhetorical strategies they have used in the past. Black people use these blogs to crtique aspects scoiety as well as assert their Blackness. The comparison of online platforms as Black barbershops and beauty shops contributes to this digital edition project considering an immense amount of effort has been made to amplify Black twitter users, bloggers, and Youtubers. The language used to describe the Black Panther movie, specifically the language used to describe the impact of a movie that centralizes accurate representations of Black people has been mplified in this project.

analytic.title: Defying Death: Black Joy as Resistance Online

biblStruct.note: In this article, Catherine Knight Steele and Jessica Lu explore the rhetoric used by Black twitter users. They found that various hastags, memes, and other practices have been used by Black people as a form of resistance. This resistance stems from the lack of postive representation that Black people recieve in film and the media in general. The portrayals of Black joy online has been used to humanize Black people. This contributes to the project considering we have focused on amlifying and perserving the postive rhetoric throughout online spaces used to describe the Black Panther movie. The response from Black people after the release of this movie exemplifies the fact that Blackness does not always have to correlate to sadness and death but rather intellegence, technological adnvancement, and strength.

hyphenation.p: Except where normalization disrupts the formatting of the digital surrogate when rendered online, all end-of-line hyphenation in the original source material has been reformed. The choice element has been used to enclose orig and reg elements giving the original hyphenation and regularized version, respectively.

normalization.p: All obvious spelling and typographical errors in the original source material is corrected. The choice element has been used to enclose sic and corr elements giving the original error and correction, respectively.
Whenever necessary, spacing between words and following punctuation has been regularized to zero spaces; spacing between words has been regularized to one space.

Instances of African American Vernacular English have purposefully NOT been adjusted to comply with American English language practices. African American Vernacular English is wholly valid in its form, features, and creativity, despite the dominance and presumed correctness of American English.

editorialDecl.p: To represent changes and/or corrections made by the original source authors BEFORE the encoding process, encoders use add, del, and subst.
Encoding includes the use of supplied to provide clarificationand supporting content, including out-links to relevant digital content and citations of Black and Black-centric academic research.

normalization.p: Hashtags (#Wakanda and #BlackPanther) have been retained at the end of each tweet to emphasize the goal of the author who wrote this tweet thread. The author hoped to reach a wide range of people so that her work could be viewed by many in order to encourage conversation about African culture, tribes, and traditions depicted in Black Panther.

The emojis used in the tweet thread to show the flag of the African country that some of the characters come from has been omitted. This was done because we believe that it is not important to the actual content or importance of the text. Also, TEI has very little tags that allow for emojis to be encoded.

samplingDecl.p: Only one or two pictures were encoded from each tweet in the thread using the appropriate TEI tags. This is due to the fact that only one picture showing an aspect of African culture decpicted in Black Panther along with one picture showing African culture in the real world is sufficient enough to develop an understanding about what the author is describing in each tweet.

28 out of the 28 tweets in the thread were encoded because they were all important in terms of exemplifying the attention that was paid to accurately representing African tribes. However, none of the comments under the tweet were encoded because we believe that some of them are not important to the focus of our projet which is the impact of the representation in Black Panther.

The amount of retweets and likes of the first tweet in the thread was retained. We beleive it wass important to emphasize the popularity of this thread to point out that Twitter is a Black place in which Black twitter users interact together to provide their thoughts and feelings towards different events.

projectDesc.p: This project seeks to identify, collect, preserve, and analyze FREEDOM discourse, as constituted and argued by Black users online. Directed by Dr. Jessica H. Lu, this project is currently being advanced by several undergraduatestudents at the University of Maryland, College Park: Sophia Crooks, Kayla Graham, Kaanita Iyer, Ariana Lawson, Alice Liu, and Courtney Richardson.

This thread was encoded because it exemplifies the celebration of blackness. Black Twitter users are excited about the celebration of Black, specifically African culture and tradtions that were depicted in the Black Panther movie. These people used Twitter as a digital space to discuss aspects of their culture.

org.note: There were several African tribes amplified throughout this digital surrogate. Each tribe deserves to be amplified seperately which is why they were all given seperate xmi ids in the body of the text. The tribes are not listed seperately here but rather as a larger group because their information on the Library of Congress does not exist. This is due to the the erasure of Black people. However, we still beleive it is important that the African tribes in this film be recognized considering so many of them were represented in this film through the costumes, hair styles, makeup, and cultural customs of the characters.

person.note: Ruth Carter along with Hannah Beachler were costume designers who worked to create the Afrocentric costumes for the Black Panther film. Ruth as a Black woman costume designer was extremely important to the film because she did an amazing job at providing so much representation from multiple African tribes.

Hannah Beachler along with Ruth Carter were costume designers who worked to create the Afrocentric costumes for the Black Panther film. She also did an amazing job at providing representation in the film and making sure the costumes that the characters wore were accurate. Her Library of Congress information is not listed simply because it does not exist. This emphasizes the fact that many Black people, but specifically Black women in particular have been silenced.

Danai Gurira is an actress and she played Okoye in Black Panther. She along with many of the other Black women in this film provided representation that was very needed; Black women as strong, independent, intellegent beings.

Lupita Nyong'o is an actress and model. She starred in Black Panther as Nakia in Black Panther. Herself along with Letita Wright, Angela Basset, and Danai Gurira portrayed strong, intellgent, and independent Black women in this film. Lupita is important for this project because she was important for a alot of Black women who had been waiting for this type of representation in film. Many Black women took to twitter to describe her character and how it impacted them.

listChange.change: The B in Black was capitalized throughout the text to amplify Black people, made on November 9, 2018.

One or more pictures from each tweet containing more than two pictures were removed because only one picture from the moive as well as one from the real world was sufficient enough to understand the author's purpose of the tweet, made on April 9, 2018.

supplied.supplied: Thread on African tribes/cultures featured in #BlackPanther. #Wakanda

div.p: 41,132 Retweets 55,784 Likes

Mursi and Surma Lip Plates. Lip plates or disks are a form of ceremonial body modification. While many cultures use them they're best known by the Surma and Mursi tribes in Ethiopia. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This figure depicts characters of a specific tribe in the movie Black Panther. The tribe leader wears a Surma or Mursi lip plate as described by the author of this tweet thread.
This picture is of a women who belongs to an actual Surma or Mursi tribe in Ethiopia. She wears a lip plate which is simliar to the tribe leader character in the movie.

div.p: Zulu headdress. Queen Ramonda wears a distinct headdress. It's reminiscent of the reed Zulu flared hats or "Isicholos." The Zulu headdresses are traditionally worn by married women for ceremonial celebrations.

figure.figDesc: This picture is a collage of four different pictures. Two of the pictures show the character, Queen Romonda, wearing a traditional Zulu headdress in the film. The other two pictures show two real life women who wear the "Isicholos".

div.p: Many of the costumes have unique and futuristic ornamentation and details. These were made by emulating styles of the Masai people Maasai people. The Maasai people of East Africa live in southern Kenya and northern Tanzania. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This picture depicts the "futuristic" costumes worn by some of the characters in the movie.
This picture is of a group of actual Maasai people. It can be seen that the costumes used in the film were influenced by the tradtional attire of this group of people.

div.p: Igbo Mask. In one scene Erik Killmonger wears a mask. The masks, known as Mgbedike, are distinguished by the large size and bold masculine features. They are used in Igbo rituals and are designed to contrast the female dancers with their more feminine beauty. #BlackPanther

figure.figDesc: This picture shows the character, Erik Killmonger, wearing a tradtional Igbo Mask.
This picure shows a side-by-side of Erik Killmonger wearing an Igbo mask in the movie and an actual Igbo mask that has been displayed in what looks like a museuem.

div.p: Basotho Blanket. In several scenes, W'Kabi (Daniel Kaluuya) and others are shown wearing Basotho blankets around their necks. Though the blankets are originally from the Lesotho people the designs are synonymous with the Sesotho people. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This picture is a collage made up of three different pictures. one of the pictures shows the character, W'Kabi, wearing an article of clothing that is simliar to a Basotho blanket. The other two photos show two other men who wear the Basotho blanket in the real world.

div.p: Ndebele Neck Rings. Shuri and the Dora Milaje have outfits with a prominent collar. The South Ndebele peoples of Zimbabwe and South Africa wear neck rings as part of their traditional dress and as a sign of wealth and status. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This photo is of the character, Dora Milaje, wearing a costume with a "prominent collar" which is similar to the tradtitonal Ndebele neck rings.
This photo is of a women wearing tradtional Ndebele neck rings.

div.p: Many of the costumes have a distinctive red earthy tone. This was done by studying the colors used by the Himba people of north-western North WesternNamibia. Himba people are known for applying a red ochre paste, known as "otjize", to their skin and hair. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This collage shows all three of the pictures used by the author to depict the Himba people of North Western Namibia. One picture shows a tribe leader in the film who has applied red ochre paste like the two women in the other two photos who use "otjize" on their skin and hair in real life.

div.p: Forest Whittaker plays shaman Zuri who's the spiritual leader of Wakanda. He wears ornate flowing robes known as an Agbada. It's one of the names for a flowing wide-sleevedwide sleeved robe worn by men/women in much of West Africa ,and North Africa. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This image is of the character, shaman Zuri, along with another character in the film. They both wear costumes that resemble traditional Agbada.

div.p: There was a lot of inspiration taken from the Dogonpeople. They live in the central plateau region of Mali, in West Africa. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This is an image of three Dogon men in their ceremonial attire, which influenced many of Black Panther costumes.

div.p: Tuaregscarfs. Several characters in the film wear large scarves covering their head and face. These are similar to the ones worn by the Tuareg people. The Tuareg people inhabit an area in North and West Africa. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This is a collage of all four of the pictures that they author used to match her description of the Tuareg scarf. One of the pictures is a screenshoot from the Black Panther movie which contains characters wearing Tuareg scarfs. The other three pictures show men and women in real life wearing the Tuareg scarf.

div.p: Other tribes of sartorial inspiration were the Turkana people in Kenya. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This picture is of three women from the Turkana tribe in Kenya wearing large beaded neck rings which inspired the creation of some of the costumes in the film.

div.p: The language spoken in #Wakanda is Xhosa, a language spoken by over 19 million people in Southern Africa.

figure.figDesc: This is a map of South Africa that has shaded percentages of how many people speak the Xhosa language, the primary language used by African characters in the film.

div.p: Danai Gurira is from Zimbabwe

figure.figDesc: This is photo of Danai Gurira as her character, Okoye during one of the scenes in the film.

div.p: Florence Kasumba is from Uganda

figure.figDesc: Pictured here is screenshot of Florence Kasumba as the charcter, Ayo in her Wakandan military uniform.

div.p: Daniel Kaluuya is from Uganda

figure.figDesc: This is a screenshoot from the film. Daniel Kaluuya iss seen acting as the character W'Kabi while wearing his traditonal attire.

div.p: Lupita Nyong'o is from Kenya

figure.figDesc: Here is a photo of Lupita Nyong'o as the charcter Nakia dressed in an Wakandan miltary uniform.

div.p: John Kani is from South Africa

figure.figDesc: This is a headshot of T'chaka played by the South African actor John Kani.

div.p: Did y'all catch when our sis Lupitabegins the film fighting for enslaved girls in Nigeria. Lupita learned to speak Hausa for certain scenes in the film. She also trained in judo, jujitsu, silat and Filipino martial arts.
Michael B. Jordan's bumpy, ritualistic tribal markings on his chest and torse resemble the scar tattoos of the Mursi and Surma tribes in Ethiopia. #Black Panther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This is an image of Michael B Jordan as Erik Killmonger who has bumpy tribal markings all over his torso and chest.

div.p: T'Challa's Kente scarf. Kente, known as nwentom in Akan, is a type of silk and cotton fabric made of interwoven cloth strips and is native to the Akan people of Ghana.#BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: Here is a collage of photos that include two images of T'Challa, played by Chadwick Boseman, wearing a Kente scarf around his neck as well as photos of Africans in the real world wearing Kente fabric.

div.p: The Black women who spent months researching and making #Wakanda come to life. Ruth Carter - costume designer and Hannah Beachler - production designer. #Black Panther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This is a picture of the costume designer for Black Panther, Ruth E. Carter, standing in what looks like a studio in which she designed the costumes for the characters in Black Panther.
Pictured here is Hannah Beachler, the production designer for Black Panther, on the red carpet.

div.p: Did y'all hear this song? ItsIt'sfrom South Africa. Babes wodumo ft Mamointsha - Wololo #Black Panther #Wakanda

media.desc: This is 3 minute and 56 second music video of the song Babes wodumo Ft Mampintsha - Wololo which was played during the film.

div.p: Can we take a moment to appreciate how Africans across the continent came out for #Black Panther movie premiere! This is Lagos Nigeria. #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: In this picture there four Black people in traditonal African attire at the premiere of Black Panther in Lagos, Nigeria.

div.p: #BlackPanther movie premiere in Kisumu, Kenya. #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: Pictued here are four Black people in traditional African attire attending the Black Panther premiere in Kissumu, Kenya.

div.p: The Great Rift Valley. Scientists have estimated that the Great Rift Valley found in Kenya was formed over 20 million years ago when the Earth's crust began to split. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This is a picture of a man standing on a cliff overlooking the Great Rift Valley in Kenya. This valley shows similarities to the valley of Wakanda in the film.

This is a picture is taken from the Black Panther poster. The author has cut the bottom of the poster off to emphasize the character, Black Panther, standing on the Black Panther shaped cliff of Wakanda. This cliff and the view from it resemble the Great Rift Valley of Kenya.

div.p: Tribal make-upmakeup is practiced in many African tribes.The make-upmakeup, often in the form of face paint, is used for many different reasons and can signify many different things such as hunting, religious and traditional reasons, military purposes or to scare an enemy. #BlackPanther

figure.figDesc: This is an image of Letitia Wright as the charcter Shuri, who wears paint on her face, very simliar to tribal makeup used by African tribes.

div.p: #BlackPanther was totally a Afrocentric natural hair movie. Inspiration came from this collection of blackBlack hairstyles shot by the Nigerian photographer J.D. ’Okhai Ojeikere. #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This is a picture of girl with a natural Black hairstyle which was included in the collection of photos by the Nigerian photographer J. D. ’Okhai Ojeikere.
